title: Quantitative and qualitative analysis of methanogenic communities in mesophilically and psychrophilically cultivated anaerobic granular biofilims
abstract: Anaerobic granulation describes the self-immobilisation of methanogenic consortia into dense, particulate biofilms. This procedure underpins the operation of several categories of high-rate anaerobic wastewater treatment system. Full-scale anaerobic granular sludge plants have been generally operated in the mesophilic (20–45 °C) or thermophilic (45–65 °C) temperature range. On the other hand, recent studies highlighted the economic advantages of treating wastewaters at their discharge temperatures (mostly under 18 °C), removing a costly heating process and increasing net biogas yield. However, as yet, relatively little information is available about the microbial behaviour and interactions in anaerobic granular sludge formed under psychrophilic conditions. To this end, and in order to provide a microbial insight into low-temperature anaerobic granulation, we monitored the changes in methanogenic community structure, associated with the changes in process performance. Three, laboratory-scale, expanded granular sludge bed (EGSB) bioreactors treating a synthetic glucose wastewater were tested at two temperatures of 37 ± 1 °C (R1) and 15 ± 1 °C (R2 and 3). Quantitative real-time PCR and specific methanogenic activity assays highlighted a community shift towards hydrogenotrophic methanogens, particularly the order Methanomicrobiales in the low-temperature bioreactors. Corresponding to this, denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) analysis identified the emergence and maintenance of a Methanocorpusculum-like organism. Our results indicate that hydrogenotrophic methanogens, particularly the Methanomicrobiales-related populations, are likely to play important roles in low-temperature anaerobic granular sludge systems. This suggests that the process efficiency could be improved by facilitating the growth and retention of this group

Quantitative and qualitative analysis of methanogenic communities in mesophilically 1

ABSTRACT 1 
 2 
Anaerobic granulation describes the self-immobilisation of methanogenic consortia into dense, 3 
particulate biofilms. This procedure underpins the operation of several categories of high-rate 4 
anaerobic wastewater treatment system. Full-scale anaerobic granular sludge plants have been 5 
generally operated in the mesophilic (20-45°C) or thermophilic (45-65°C) temperature range. 6 
On the other hand, recent studies highlighted the economic advantages of treating wastewaters 7 
at their discharge temperatures (mostly under 18°C), removing a costly heating process and 8 
increasing net biogas yield. However, as yet, relatively little information is available about the 9 
microbial behaviour and interactions in anaerobic granular sludge formed under psychrophilic 10 
conditions. To this end, and in order to provide a microbial insight into low-temperature 11 
anaerobic granulation, we monitored the changes in methanogenic community structure, 12 
associated with the changes in process performance. Three, laboratory-scale, expanded 13 
granular sludge bed (EGSB) bioreactors treating a synthetic glucose wastewater were tested at 14 
two temperatures of 37 ± 1 °C (R1) and 15 ± 1 °C (R2 and 3). Quantitative real-time PCR and 15 
specific methanogenic activity assays highlighted a community shift towards 16 
hydrogenotrophic methanogens, particularly the order Methanomicrobiales in the low-17 
temperature bioreactors. Corresponding to this, denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis 18 
(DGGE) analysis identified the emergence and maintenance of a Methanocorpusculum-like 19 
organism. Our results indicate that hydrogenotrophic methanogens, particularly the 20 
Methanomicrobiales-related populations, are likely to play important roles in low-temperature 21 
anaerobic granular sludge systems. This suggests that the process efficiency could be 22 
improved by facilitating the growth and retention of this group. 23 
Keywords:  DGGE; Low-temperature anaerobic digestion; Granular biofilm; Methanogenic 24 
community, Quantitative real-time PCR25

1. Introduction 1 
 2 
Anaerobic digestion is an attractive option for treating wastewaters containing biodegradable 3 
organic matter due to the ability to reduce pollution load and produce energy simultaneously. 4 
Wastewater carbon is converted to biogas, mainly methane, and in effect the treatment process 5 
becomes a net producer of energy (Liu et al., 2003; Hulshoff Pol et al., 2004; Collins et al., 6 
2006). Additionally, anaerobic digestion does not require costly aeration and produces less 7 
sludge for disposal, indicating that it is generally more economically efficient than aerobic 8 
systems (McCarty, 2001). Anaerobic granular biofilms are formed via the self-immobilisation 9 
of the microbial populations distributed within the domains Archaea and Bacteria. The biofilm 10 
structure, particularly in granular sludge, has underpinned the development of several 11 
categories of high rate anaerobic wastewater treatments conferring a number of advantages 12 
over conventional processes (McCarty, 2001). 13 
Most full-scale anaerobic digesters are operated at mesophilic or thermophilic 14 
temperatures (Liu et al., 2003; Hulshoff Pol et al., 2004). Ambient or sub-ambient treatments 15 
were considered unattractive due to lower microbial activity and increased viscosity of liquids 16 
(Rebac et al., 1999; Lettinga et al., 2001). However, the majority of industrial effluents are 17 
discharged at ≤ 18°C (Connaughton et al., 2006a), resulting in considerable heating costs for 18 
mesophilic or thermophilic operation. Therefore, economic feasibility of anaerobic digestion 19 
could be enhanced by treating wastewaters at their discharge temperatures, resulting in a net 20 
increase in energy yield (Lettinga et al., 2001). A number of successful low-temperature 21 
anaerobic digestion trials, treating various synthetic and real wastewaters, have demonstrated 22 
robust and stable operation with comparable performance to mesophilic systems. However, 23 
these studies used anaerobic granular sludge which was pre-granulated under mesophilic 24 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 4
conditions, although the microbial populations gradually became psychrotolerent (Collins et 1 
al., 2005; Connaughton et al., 2006a; McHugh et al., 2006). 2 
Most studies on the fundamental microbial interactions in anaerobic digestion have 3 
focused on bioreactors operating under mesophilic and thermophilic conditions. Previous 4 
studies revealed the importance of aceticlastic methanogens, particularly belonging to the 5 
family Methanosaetaceae, for the stable operation of anaerobic digesters (El-Mamouni et al., 6 
1997; Diaz et al., 2006; Satoh et al., 2007). Efforts at altering digester operating conditions 7 
have been made to facilitate the growth and retention of high levels of Methanosaeta 8 
populations, greatly improving granule formation as well as process efficiency (Liu et al., 9 
2002; Hulshoff Pol et al., 2004). Currently, there is a dearth of basic information on microbial 10 
behaviour and interactions in anaerobic granular sludges cultivated at psychrophilic 11 
temperatures. Several critical questions have yet to be addressed: “Can granular biofilms be 12 
effectively cultivated at low-temperatures?” and “What are the numerically or functionally 13 
important populations?” This study focused on these knowledge gaps. 14 
Three lab-scale expanded granular sludge bed (EGSB) bioreactors treating a synthetic 15 
glucose wastewater were operated at mesophilic (R1, 37 ± 1 °C) and psychrophilic (R2 and 3, 16 
15 ± 1 °C) temperatures. Formation of granular biofilm was successfully demonstrated in each 17 
bioreactor. Methanogenic community structure and population dynamics, assoicated with low-18 
temperature granulation, was assessed by a combination of molecular and statistical tools. The 19 
qualitative and quantitative changes in methanogenic community composition were monitored 20 
using denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) and real-time PCR techniques. 21 
 22 
MATERIALS AND METHODS 23 
 24 
Operation of EGSB bioreactors 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 5
 1 
Anaerobic granular sludge (∅, 0.8-3.5 mm) was obtained from a full-scale internal circulation 2 
digester (Carbery Milk Products Ltd, Balineen, Co. Cork, Ireland) treating industrial alcohol 3 
production wastewater at 37°C. The granular biomass was crushed and graded by sieving (∅ 4 
< 0.4 mm), and subsequently 88 g of volatile solids (VS) were used to seed three identical 5 
EGSB bioreactors, with 4-L working volumes, denoted as R1 to 3. All bioreactors were 6 
operated under the same conditions except temperature. R1 was operated at 37 ± 1°C, while 7 
both R2 and 3 were maintained at 15 ± 1°C. Each system was operated at a 12-h hydraulic 8 
retention time (HRT) to treat a synthetic glucose wastewater, which was buffered at pH 7.1 ± 9 
0.2 with NaHCO3 and fortified with trace elements (mg/L): NiCl2·6H20 (0.712), CoCl2·6H20 10 
(0.202), Na2Mo4·2H20 (0.126), FeCl2·6H20 (0.203) and yeast extract (170). The trial was 11 
divided into 5 phases, which were characterised by changes applied to the upflow velocity or 12 
organic loading. Glucose was the sole carbon source in the wastewater and its content was 13 
adjusted with respect to the organic loading rate (OLR). An OLR of 5.8 kg chemical oxygen 14 
demand (COD)/m3/d was applied during Phases 1 to 4, and upon the commencement of Phase 15 
5, the rate was dropped to 2.8 kg COD/m3/d. The bioreactor effluent and biogas were 16 
routinely sampled for COD, pH, and CH4 content. 17 
 18 
Specific methanogenic activity test 19 
 20 
The specific methanogenic activity (SMA) of bioreactor biomass was determined at 30 d and 21 
194 d, using the pressure transducer technique (Colleran et al., 1992). The substrates assayed 22 
were acetate (30 mM) and H2/CO2 (80:20, v/v) (Colleran et al., 1992; Coates et al., 1996). 23 
Each assay was conducted with 3 g VS/L of biomass in triplicate. Each biomass sample was 24 
tested at the operating temperature of its corresponding bioreactor. 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 6
 1 
Granulation rate determination 2 
 3 
The granulation rate was defined as the proportion of granules of which diameter is larger 4 
than 1.0 mm in the total biomass dry weight. The granulation rate of bioreactor biomass was 5 
determined every 30-35 d. Approximately 30 mL of sludge from each bioreactor was graded 6 
in a step wise manner using sieves (pore sizes, 1.4, 1.25, 1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.4 and 0.2 mm). Each 7 
biomass size fraction was dried at 110°C for 24 h. The granulation rate was calculated based 8 
on dry weight. 9 
 10 
DNA extraction 11 
 12 
Total DNA was extracted from bioreactor sludge granules (∅ > 1.0 mm) using an automated 13 
nucleic acid extractor (Magtration System 12 GC, PSS Co., Chiba, Japan) (Lee et al., 2008). 14 
Prior to extraction, each sample (0.5 g wet weight) was finely crushed using a mortar and 15 
pestle, and resuspended in 50 mL of double distilled water. A 100-μL aliquot of the 16 
resuspended biomass sample was loaded per extraction. In parallel, the VS concentration of 17 
each resuspension was measured to estimate the exact amount of biomass used for DNA 18 
extraction. The extracted DNA was eluted in Tris-HCl buffer (pH 8.0) and stored at -20°C. 19 
All extractions were carried out in duplicate. 20 
 21 
DGGE and phylogenetic analyses 22 
 23 
Archaeal community profiles were investigated by DGGE analysis targeting the 16S rRNA 24 
gene. Conventional PCR was performed using primers 787F and 1059R (Takai and 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 7
Horikoshi, 2000). A 40-bp GC-clamp was attached at the 5’-end of the forward primer for 1 
stabilizing the melting behaviour of the PCR products (Muyzer et al., 1993). The PCR 2 
amplification was performed as follows: initial denaturation at 95°C for 3 min; a touch-down 3 
thermal cycling of denaturation at 95°C for 1.5 min, annealing at 65 to 55°C for 1.5 min 4 
(reducing 1°C per cycle), and elongation at 72°C for 1.5 min; additional 20 cycles of 95°C for 5 
1.5 min, 55°C for 1.5 min, 72°C for 1.5 min. A 20 μL aliquot of each PCR product was 6 
loaded onto a 10% (w/v) polyacrylamide gel containing a denaturing gradient of 30 to 60% 7 
(100% denaturant contained 7 M urea and 40% (v/v) formamide). Electrophoresis was run in 8 
a D-Code system (BioRad, Hercules, CA). The DGGE gel was ethidium bromide-stained and 9 
photographed under UV transillumination. A binary matrix was constructed from the gel 10 
image by scoring the presence or absence of each band with a 1 or 0, and then statistically 11 
analyzed based on Sorensen (Bray-Curtis) distance measure using MVSP software (Kovach 12 
Computing Services, Pentraeth, UK) to build an unweighted pair group method arithmetic 13 
mean (UPGMA) cluster tree. 14 
In parallel, for phylogenetic analysis, bands of interest were excised from the gel using 15 
a sterile scalpel blade. For accurate correlation of band homology between two DGGE gels, a 16 
selected number of bands (i.e., J1, J5 and J7) were double-checked from both gels (Fig 2). 17 
The excised bands were eluted in 25 μL of sterile water, and then reamplified with the same 18 
primers (without GC-clamp). The PCR products were gel-purified and cloned into the TOPO 19 
TA 2.1 vector (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA). The sequence of each PCR fragment was 20 
determined by sequencing with M13 primer and compared against the GenBank and RDP II 21 
databases. A neighbour-joining tree was constructed using MEGA 4 software (Tamura et al., 22 
2007). All nucleotide sequences reported in this study were deposited in the GenBank 23 
database under accession numbers FJ657373-FJ657380. 24 
 25 
M
AN

PT

ARTICLE IN PRESS
 8
Real-time PCR analysis 1 
 2 
Real-time PCR was performed with five primer/probe sets (Table 1), which cover most 3 
methanogens present in anaerobic digesters (Yu et al., 2005; Lee et al., 2008), using a 4 
LightCycler 1.2 (Roche, Mannheim, Germany). Each reaction mixture was prepared using the 5 
LightCycler TaqMan Master kit (Roche): 8 μL of PCR-grade water, 1 μL of the probe (final 6 
concentration 200 nM), 1 μL of each primer (final concentration 500 nM), 4 μL of 5× 7 
reaction solution, and 5 μL of DNA template. Amplification was carried out using a two-step 8 
thermal cycling protocol consisted of predenaturation for 10 min at 94°C followed by 40 9 
cycles of 10 s at 94oC and 30 s at 60oC (except 63oC for MMB-set). 10 
Quantitative standard curves were constructed as previously described (Yu et al., 11 
2006) using the representative strains corresponding to each primer/probe sets used (Table 1). 12 
A total of 12 standard plasmids containing the full-length 16S rRNA gene sequences of the 13 
representative strains, were kindly provided by Prof. S. Hwang, POSTECH, Korea (Yu et al., 14 
2005). For each set, an equimolar mixture of its corresponding plasmids was used as the 15 
standard solution. The mass concentration of each standard plasmid was measured in 16 
duplicate using a Qubit system (Invitrogen) and converted to its copy concentration as 17 
previously described (Lee et al., 2006; Yu et al., 2006). For each standard solution, a 10-fold 18 
serial dilution series of 101 to 109 copies/μL was generated and analyzed by real-time PCR in 19 
triplicate with its corresponding primer/probe set. The threshold cycle (CT) values determined 20 
were plotted against the logarithm of their input copy concentrations. The 16S rRNA gene 21 
copy concentrations of target groups were then estimated against the corresponding standard 22 
curves within the linear range (r2 > 0.995). The volume based concentration (copies/μL) was 23 
converted to the granule biomass based concentration (copies/g granule VS) using the VS 24 
M

CE
PT

ARTICLE IN PRESS
 9
concentration of each granular sludge sample used for DNA extraction. All DNA samples 1 
from each bioreactor were analyzed with each primer/probe set in duplicate. 2 
 3 
Analytical methods 4 
 5 
Solids and COD were analyzed following the procedure in Standard Methods (APHA-6 
AWWA-WEF, 2005). Methane content was determined using a Philips PYE unicam series 7 
304  gas chromatograph (Cambridge, UK) equipped with a packed capillary column (Propak 8 
Q 100-120 mesh). Nitrogen was used as a carrier gas at a flow rate of 60 mL/min. All samples 9 
were analysed in duplicate. 10 
 11 
RESULTS 12 
 13 
Bioreactor performance 14 
 15 
Fig. 1 shows the COD removal efficiency profiles of the bioreactors R1 to 3 during the trial 16 
(i.e., Operational Phases 1 to 5). The operating parameters and performances are summarized 17 
in Table 2. The methane content was maintained at around 59-72% in R1 through out the trial, 18 
whereas it increased from 32-34% to 60-65% upon completion of the trial in R2 and 3 (Table 19 
2). During the start-up period (Phase 1), COD removal efficiency remained at around 90% or 20 
higher after 20 d of operation in R1, whereas only approximately 60% removal was observed 21 
in both R2 and 3. Within the same phase, the granulation ratio was also significantly higher in 22 
R1 (63%) than in R2 and 3 (18-22%). This trend in granulation continued during Phase 2, 23 
where the upflow velocity was increased from 0.17 to 0.5 m/h. During this phase, the R1 24 
granulation rate increased to 78% but low rates of 19-20% were still maintained in R2 and R3. 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 10
During the Phases 2 to 5, the COD removal efficiency in R1 mostly remained above 95%. 1 
The upflow velocity was adjusted and maintained at 1 m/h during Phase 3, which was marked 2 
by a significant drop in COD removal efficiency (< 50%) in R2 and 3 (Fig. 1). In this phase, 3 
the sludge beds in both bioreactors were highly compacted and pistoned severely. This was 4 
likely caused by the prevailing liquid viscosity at the low operating temperature, which 5 
probably resulted in cumulative compaction of the sludge bed during the previous 90 days of 6 
operation. During Phase 4, the upflow velocity was doubled to 2 m/h and the low-temperature 7 
bioreactors recovered from performance deterioration and exhibited 60-70% of COD removal 8 
efficiencies. Correspondingly, the granulation ratio, which was maintained at approximately 9 
20% during Phase 1 to 3, also increased to between 29 and 33% in this phase. In Phase 5, the 10 
OLR was decreased by 50% to 2.9 kg COD/m3/d and R1 kept a high bioreactor performance 11 
of > 95% COD removal. On the other hand, the COD removal efficiencies in R2 and 3 were ≤ 12 
80% (Fig 2). A notable finding was the significant increase in the ratio of hydrogenotrophic to 13 
aceticlastic SMA values in the low-temperature bioreactors (Table 2). Throughout the trial, 14 
the ratio increased by between 2.1 and 3.3 fold in R2 and 3, whereas no significant change 15 
occurred in the ratio of the mesophilic R1 (Table 2). Furthermore, the ratios measured in 16 
Phase 1 highlighted that hydrogenotrophic activity was likely to be significantly higher (2.5-17 
3.3 fold) than aceticlastic activity under low-temperature conditions, even in the early stage of 18 
operation (Table 2). 19 
 20 
Archaeal DGGE profiles 21 
 22 
Comparative PCR-DGGE analysis of the methanogenic granular biofilm communities under 23 
mesophilic and psychrophillic conditions identified temperature-dependent differences in the 24 
community structures (Fig. 2). The R1 mesophilic community displayed no significant 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 11
temporal variation and the community profiles analysed at different time points throughout 1 
the operation clustered closely together with ≥ 92% similarity. This implies that the 2 
qualitative methanogenic community structure (i.e., population diversity) in R1 was 3 
reasonably consistent, despite the modification of operating parameters, throughout the trial. 4 
The DGGE profiles from two low-temperature bioreactors (i.e., R2 and 3) were highly similar 5 
to each other and clustered closely together at each sampling point (Fig 2). A total of 8 bands 6 
(J1 to 8) were retrieved from the archaeal DGGE gel and several ribotypes were found (Fig 3). 7 
J1, which appeared at 30 d in R1 and at 90 d in R2 and 3, was closely related to 8 
Methanocorpusculum parvum, with 99.6% similarity (Table 3). This band also corresponded 9 
to two other species within the same genus, M. bavaricum and M. labreanum. J2 to 4 were 10 
only detected in R1 from 30 d onwards and showed 95.5 to 100% similarity to 11 
Methanospirillium hungatei. J8, which appeared only in R2 and 3 from 120 d onwards, was 12 
closely related to two Methanosarcina species, M. mazei and M. lacustris, with 100% 13 
similarity. The remaining three bands were commonly detected in all DGGE lanes (Fig 2). J5 14 
and 6 were related to Methanosaeta concilii (98.5-98.8%) and J7 was related to 15 
Methanobacterium beijingeise (100%; Table 3). Consequently, 5 out of the 8 deduced 16 
sequences were affiliated with hydrogenotrophic methanogens (J1 to 4 and 7) and the 17 
remaining three were with aceticlastic methanogens (J5, 6 and 8). 18 
 19 
Quantitative analysis of methanogenic community 20 
 21 
The real-time PCR results showed clear changes in the quantitative composition of the 22 
methanogenic community of each bioreactor over time (Fig. 4). In the seed sludge, in terms of 23 
16S rRNA gene concentration, the aceticlastic family Methanosaetaceae was absolutely 24 
dominant (98% of the measured methanogenic population, i.e., the sum of all 16S rRNA gene 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 12
concentrations quantified with the primer/probe sets used). This corresponds to the previously 1 
reported high abundance of Methanosaetaceae-related species in stable granular anaerobic 2 
digesters (Diaz et al., 2006; Satoh et al., 2007; Fernandez et al., 2008). In R1, the 3 
Methanosaetaceae 16S rRNA gene concentration decreased by about 100 folds, along with a 4 
100-fold increase in Methanobacteriales, after 30 d of operation. The Methanosaetaceae 5 
concentration increased again up to 8.5 × 1010 copies/g granule VS and remained at around 6 
1010 level. On the other hand, Methanobacteriales showed no significant change during the 7 
trial and remained at a reasonably constant level. Methanomicrobiales also showed a 8 
considerable increase, particularly after 30 d, and the three methanogenic groups detected in 9 
R1 showed similar 16S rRNA gene levels of 2.9 to 4.7 × 1010 copies/g granule VS at trial 10 
completion at 194 d. Interestingly, no detectable level of Methanosarcinaceae population was 11 
found in R1, which maintained a high treatment efficiency throughout the trial (Table 2). 12 
The two low-temperature bioreactors showed similar patterns in quantitative 13 
community dynamics. Contrary to R1, Methanosaetaceae was missing during the early period 14 
and Methanosarcinaceae was detected in the later period of operation in R2 and 3. A notable 15 
difference between the mesophilic and psychrophilic bioreactors is the dramatic drop and 16 
regrowth of the hydrogenotrophic order Methanomicrobiales, becoming the most abundant 17 
group in the later period under low-temperature conditions. In both R2 and 3, its 16S rRNA 18 
gene concentration increased up to about 1.0 × 1011 copies/g granule VS and comprised 66.7-19 
77.2% of the total measured methanogenic population at the end of the trial. In comparison, 20 
the other three methanogenic groups were detected at abundances of around 1.0 × 1010 21 
copies/g granule VS. 22 
Consequently, our quantification results clearly demonstrated the significantly higher 23 
abundance of hydrogenotrophic populations, particularly Methanomicrobiales group, in the 24 
low-temperature bioreactors than in the mesophilic one. This indicates that the methanogenic 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 13
activities in R2 and 3 were probably significantly more dependent on hydrogenotrophic 1 
metabolism. The order Methanobacteriales exhibited a relatively even distribution in each 2 
bioreactor tested, and the order Methanococcales was not detected at any trial point. In this 3 
study, the real-time PCR detection limit for each primer/probe set was < 107 copies/g granule 4 
VS level. 5 
 6 
DISCUSSION 7 
 8 
High COD removal efficiency of around 95% was observed in R1 during the trial, whereas it 9 
was considerably lower (ca. 60-70%) in R2 and 3. The granulation rate was also significantly 10 
higher (ca. 2.4-4.1 fold) in R1 (Table 2). The replicated low-temperature bioreactors, R2 and 3, 11 
showed reproducible performance (Fig. 1), and the methanogenic community compositions of 12 
the reactors, qualitatively and quantitatively analyzed by DGGE and real-time PCR analyses, 13 
were also highly comparable. These results suggest that the low-temperature bioreactors were 14 
reproducible in terms of microbial dynamics as well as system performance. 15 
The clustering analysis of the archaeal DGGE profiles demonstrated that the qualitative 16 
archaeal community structures changed significantly during the initial 90 d, and that they 17 
remained relatively constant (> 92% similarity) afterwards in R2 and 3. This notable variation 18 
during the early period of operation seems to be, at least partly, due to the adaption of 19 
methanogens from the mesophilic seed inoculum to low-temperature conditions. In R1, the 20 
greatest variation with 30% distance was observed between the seed and 30-d samples, and the 21 
community structure varied little (< 6% distance) during the remaining period. This may reflect 22 
the faster establishment of a stable granular methanogenic community, developed from the 23 
mesophilic seed inoculum, under mesophilic conditions in R1, which would be expectable. 24 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 14
Concerning the real-time PCR quantification, it should be mentioned that the order 1 
Methanococcales was not detected in any sample assayed. This absence of Methanococcales-2 
related organisms was probably due to their growth requirement of high salt conditions (0.3 to 3 
9.4% (w/v) NaCl) (Boone et al., 2001). Methanobacteriales was detected in the seed and all 4 
bioreactor samples. Its population varied little, except during the initial 30 d period, and was 5 
mostly maintained at above 1.0 x 1010 copies/g granule VS in all bioreactors. Among the 6 
DGGE band sequences, J7 related to M. beijingens was the only one affiliated with the order 7 
Methanobacteriales (Table 3). This species has previously been isolated from anaerobic 8 
digesters treating paper mill wastewater (Ma et al., 2005). Although its optimum growth 9 
temperature is known to be 37°C, the growth of the members of the same genus has been 10 
reported at temperatures as low as 4°C (Metje and Frenzel, 2007), supporting its potential to 11 
adapt to psychrophilic conditions. 12 
The family Methanosaetaceae was the most abundant group in the seed biomass, but 13 
its quantitative dynamics differed markedly according to the operating temperature (Fig. 4). 14 
Although the two Methanosaeta concilii-related bands, J5 and 6, were found in all DGGE 15 
lanes (Fig. 2), the Methanosaetaceae 16S rRNA gene concentration was under the real-time 16 
PCR detection limit at 30 and 90 d in R2 and at 30 d in R3. Interestingly, at around 90 d, R2 17 
and 3 exhibited virtually the only disagreement in process performance, that is, the sudden 18 
temporary increase in COD removal efficiency from < 60% to > 80% in R3 (Fig. 1). The 19 
reasons for which remain unclear, however, it was well correlated with the detection of high 20 
abundance (i.e., 1.0 x 1011 copies/g granule VS) of Methanosaetaceae, a dominant and vital 21 
methanogenic group under stable conditions (Hulshoff Pol et al., 2004; Diaz et al., 2006), at 90 22 
d in R3 only. On the other hand, no apparent relationship between the biomass granulation rate 23 
and the abundance of Methanosaetaceae was found in all bioreactors, which is inconsistent 24 
with previous reports that the Methanosaeta species play a major role in anaerobic granulation 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 15
(Liu et al., 2002; Hulshoff Pol et al., 2004). Additionally, the rapid drop and rise of 1 
Methanosaetaceae during the early period in the low-temperature bioreactors may indicate that 2 
this group was affected by cold-adaptation and is possibly sensitive to temperature change. 3 
The aceticlastic family Methanosarcinaceae appeared after 120 d of operation in R2 4 
and 3 only, but it was not detected throughout the operation in R1 (Fig. 4). Interestingly, this 5 
group appeared after the deterioration of COD removal (≤ 24%) observed in Phase 3 (Figs. 1 6 
and 4). This corresponds well to the fact that this group favours substrate rich environment (i.e., 7 
high organic acids levels) and grows faster than the other aceticlastic family Methanosaetaceae 8 
(Boone et al., 2001). Previous studies have also suggested that the members of this family are 9 
typically associated with high residual acetate concentration accompanied with process 10 
deterioration (Wiegant and Deman, 1986; Collins et al., 2003; Hulshoff Pol et al., 2004). 11 
Therefore, the appearance of this group was thought to be correlated with the bioreactor 12 
deterioration, resulting in the high accumulation of organic acids, in the low-temperature 13 
bioreactors. Corresponding to this phase, the acetate concentration in R2 and 3 was c.a. 1.2 g/L, 14 
which was almost 1000 times greater than its level in R1. Additionally, R2 and 3 exhibited 0.1-15 
0.3 g/L of propionate and 0.05-0.1 g/L of butyrate, whereas their concentrations were <5 mg/L 16 
in R1 (data not shown). Although it has been reported that the anaerobic digesters dominated 17 
by Methanosarcinaceae-related organisms are also able to perform ‘spontaneous granulation’, 18 
this type of granular biofilm tends to be less dense and to be washed out relatively easily 19 
(Hulshoff Pol et al., 2004). The DGGE band J8 affiliated with Methanosarcinaceae was 20 
assigned to M. mazei and M. lacustris with 100% similarity (Table 3). M. mazei has been 21 
frequently observed in anaerobic digestion systems (Diaz et al., 2006) and is able to utilize a 22 
variety of substrates, including acetate, H2/CO2, methanol, and methylamines (Boone et al., 23 
2001). Additionally, growth of M. mazei-like organisms have been reported at temperatures as 24 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 16
low as 5°C (Simankova et al., 2003), indicating its ability to grow under low-temperature 1 
conditions. 2 
The most intriguing observation in this study is the quantitative variation of the order 3 
Methanomicrobiales particularly in the low-temperature bioreactors (Fig. 4). This group was 4 
detected in seed biomass and all bioreactor samples, but showed significantly different 5 
dynamics under mesophilic and psychrophilic conditions. Methanomicrobiales accounted for 6 
1.5 to 44.3% of the total methanogenic 16S rRNA gene concentration in R1, whereas its 7 
abundance reached up to 66.7 to 77.2% in R2 and 3. This group showed 1200- to 8400-fold 8 
increase, from its minimum to maximum concentrations, in R2 and 3, whereas only a 54-fold 9 
increase was noted in R1. Such results indicate that this hydrogenotrophic order would be the 10 
key methanogenic group in the low-temperature bioreactors. In this study, it is not evident 11 
which factor mainly affected the high dominance of Methanomicrobiales, because the upflow 12 
velocity or OLR were changed during the 194-d experiment of cold-adaptation. However, 13 
given that a remarkable rise or high dominance of ethanomicrobiales was not shown in the 14 
mesophilic R1, operated with the same strategy as R2 and 3, low temperature seems to be the 15 
major factor facilitating the dominance of this group. Supporting this, several previous studies 16 
on mesophilic granular biofilms incubated at low temperatures have reported the temporal 17 
methanogenic community shifts towards the dominance of hydrogenotrophic methanogens, 18 
particularly Methanomicrobiales and Methanobacteriales (McHugh et al., 2004; Connaughton 19 
et al., 2006b). Although four DGGE band sequences (from J1 to 4) were assigned to the order 20 
Methanomicrobiales only J1 was detected in the low-temperature bioreactors. Interestingly, J1 21 
was solely assigned to the genus Methanocorpusculum, whereas J2 to 4 were all related to the 22 
genus Methanospirillum (Table 3). This suggests that the Methanomicrobiales community 23 
composition might be affected by the operating temperature. Our observation corresponds to 24 
the previous studies reporting increased abundance of Methanocorpusculum-like organisms 25 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
 17
during the cold adaptation of anaerobic granular sludge (Collins et al., 2003; McHugh et al., 1 
2004). Given the band intensity, although not robustly quantitative, the Methanocorpusculum-2 
like organism deduced from J1 was likely to be the major hydrogenotrophic population in the 3 
low-temperature bioreactors, particularly from 90 d onwards. This banding pattern is in good 4 
agreement with the quantification results of Methanomicrobiales (Fig. 4). On the other hand, in 5 
mesophilic R1, J1 disappeared over time even with the continuous increase in the 16S rRNA 6 
gene concentration of Methanomicrobiales, indicating the major population of this group was 7 
shifted to the others possibly including the Methanospirillum-like organisms deduced from J2 8 
to 4 (Fig. 2). 9 
The physiological profiles generated from the reactor biomass were in good agreement 10 
with the quantitative molecular studies. For example, the hydrogenotrophic SMA value was 11 
significantly higher than the aceticlastic activity in both R2 and 3, whereas they were evenly 12 
distributed in R1. Furthermore, the hydrogenotrophic to aceticlastic SMA value ratio increased 13 
significantly (2.1-3.3 times) in R2 and 3 (Table 2) as the trial progressed. This, together with 14 
the increase in and dominance of hydrogenotrophic groups, particularly Methanomicrobiales, 15 
again suggests their numerical and functional importance under low-temperature conditions. 16 
Supporting this, the dominance of hydrogenotrophs at low temperatures has been reported in 17 
several previous studies (Collins et al., 2005; Connaughton et al., 2006a; McHugh et al., 18 
2006), where very high COD removal efficiencies (>95%) were reported during low-19 
temperature anaerobic digestion. This phenomenon was proposed to be because hydrogen is 20 
thermodynamically and metabolically more favourable than acetate and higher level of 21 
hydrogen can be retained in the system (i.e., increased gas solubility) at low temperature 22 
(Lettinga et al., 2001; Kotsyurbenko, 2005). The fate of acetate in such systems remains a 23 
topic of considerable interest, with respect to the possible role of syntrophic actetate oxidation 24 
(Schnurer et al., 1994), which would be a subject of further investigation. 25

ARTICLE IN PRESS
 18
 1 
CONCLUSIONS 2 
 3 
In this study, temporal changes in the archaeal community architecture of granular biofilms 4 
were successfully related to physiological methanogenic activity profiles and reactor operating 5 
conditions. Low temperature anaerobic digestion was shown to be reproducible, both in terms 6 
of operational performance and microbial community structure. Hydrogenotrophic 7 
methanogens, from the order Methanomicrobiales, emerged as a key functional group during 8 
low-temperature anaerobic digestion. 9 
 10 
z At applied OLRs of 2.9 to 5.8 kg COD/m3/d, a moderate COD removal efficiency of 46 to 11 
74% with a biomass granulation rate of 18 to 33% was achieved at 15 ± 1 °C, while a high 12 
treatment efficiency of 93 to 98% with a biomass granulation rate of 63 to 87% was observed 13 
at 37 ± 1 °C. 14 
z The quantitative real-time PCR analysis highlighted the clear dominance shift from 15 
aceticlastic towards hydrogenotrophic methanogens, particularly the order Methanomicrobiales, 16 
in the low-temperature bioreactors. 17 
z The SMA test results also showed the evident increase in the activity of hydrogen-mediated 18 
methanogenesis (i.e., 2.1-3.3 folds), while the level of aceticlastic activity showed no change, 19 
during the trial period. 20 
z The DGGE banding patterns were in good agreement with the real-time PCR quantification 21 
results and suggested that a Methanocorpusculum-like organism was likely to be the major 22 
hydrogenotrophic population, probably mainly responsible for the dynamic changes and cold 23 
adaptation of methanogenic communities. 24 
 25
